Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the TiO2 powders (a) before and (b) after the heating process under an H2 atmosphere at 950 °C for 3 h. Fig. 2 (a) FE-SEM, (b) TEM, and (c) HR-TEM images of the resulting Ti4O7 powder. Fig. 3 Wide-range XRD patterns of (a) Pt/Ti4O7, (b) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (c) Pt/C and the (2 2 0) planes of (d) Pt/Ti4O7, (e) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (f) Pt/C. Fig. 4 TEM and HR-TEM images of (a) and (d) Pt/Ti4O7, (b) and (e) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (c) and (f) Pt/C. Fig. 5 XPS Pt4f spectra for (a) Pt/Ti4O7, (b) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (c) Pt/C. (d) XPS Ir4f spectrum for PtIr/Ti4O7. Fig. 6 (a) CVs for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C in Ar-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. (b) Comparison of EASA and ORR peak potential for the catalysts. Fig. 7 (a) LSVs of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C for ORR in O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. (b) Comparison of specific activity and half-wave potential for the catalysts. Fig. 8 (a) Polarization curves of the catalysts for OER in N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4. (b) Comparison of specific activity for the catalysts measured at 1.5 V. (c) The Tafel plots for the catalysts measured in the potential range between 1.4 and 1.6 V. Fig. 9 Comparison of the LSVs of (a) Pt/Ti4O7, (b) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (c) Pt/C for the ORR before and after the stability test. Fig. 10 Comparison of the LSVs of (a) Pt/Ti4O7, (b) PtIr/Ti4O7, and (c) Pt/C for the OER before and after the stability test. Table 1 Comparison of voltages and round-trip efficiencies for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C measured at a current density of 1.5 mA cm−2. Catalyst VORR (V) VOER (V) ɛ (%) Pt/Ti4O7 0.879 1.579 55.7 PtIr/Ti4O7 0.889 1.500 59.3 Pt/C 0.859 1.590 54.0 PtIr/Ti4O7 as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for improved oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions Ji-Eun Won Da-Hee Kwak Sang-Beom Han Hyun-Suk Park Jin-Young Park Kyeng-Bae Ma Do-Hyoung Kim Kyung-Won Park ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Soongsil University, Seoul 156-743, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical EngineeringSoongsil University Seoul 156-743 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A unitized regenerative fuel cell (URFC) that combines a fuel cell with a water electrolyzer is attractive as a portable power source. To enhance the efficiency of the URFC, a bifunctional oxygen catalyst for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) needs to be developed. In this study, Ti4O7 supported Pt-based catalysts were prepared for a bifunctional oxygen catalyst (BOC) in URFC. Ti4O7 support was prepared using a low-temperature process with TiO2 and cobalt chloride hexahydrate at 950 °C under an H2 atmosphere. The metal catalysts (60 wt%) were deposited on a Ti4O7 support using a borohydride reduction method. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Compared to Pt/C and Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited enhanced activity and stability in ORR and OER. The improved electrocatalytic performance of PtIr alloy supported by Ti4O7 might be attributed to the PtIr alloy phase, the highly stable Ti4O7 support in an acid medium, and the interaction between catalyst and support. Keywords URFC Ti4O7 Oxygen reduction Oxygen evolution Round-trip efficiency 1 Introduction A unitized regenerative fuel cell (URFC) is an energy storage system that combines a fuel cell with a water electrolyzer [1–3]. Due to its simplicity and compactness compared to the regenerative fuel cell (RFC), URFC can be extensively utilized as a portable power source for drone and military applications [4]. Furthermore, URFC exhibits higher energy density (packaged: 400–1000 Wh kg−1 and theoretical: 3660 Wh kg−1) and long-term energy storage compared to Li-ion batteries [2,5]. In the fuel cell mode of URFC, hydrogen oxidation reaction at the anode and oxidation reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode occur with the generation of electricity and water [5–7]. On the other hand, in the water electrolyzer mode, hydrogen and oxygen are electrochemically produced at the anode and cathode, respectively, using the electrolysis of water provided at the cathode [4,8]. In particular, to enhance the efficiency of URFC, the ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the cathode are essential [9]. In the cathode, a bifunctional oxygen catalyst (BOC) for both ORR and OER needs to have high electrocatalytic activity, stability in acid media, and electrical conductivity [10–12]. Currently, platinum (Pt) exhibits the excellent electrocatalytic activity towards the ORR in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) whereas iridium (Ir) and ruthenium (Ru) have an improved OER activity compared to Pt catalyst [10,13–16]. Thus, alloy structures for the BOC combined with Pt and Ir or Ru have been proposed in order to simultaneously improve the ORR/OER performance in the URFC [17–21]. In general, carbon nanostructure materials in PEMFCs can support the catalyst and increase the utilization of the catalyst [22–25]. However, in the URFC, carbon oxidation can occur in the water electrolyzer mode as follows [10,26,27]: (1) C + 2 H 2 O → CO 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - , 0.207 V vs . NHE at 25 ° C As the operation time increases, the oxidation and corrosion of the carbon support significantly increase and thus the catalytic activity of metal catalysts can decline due to the dissolution and sintering of the catalysts on the carbon supports [22,28–30]. Thus, the reduced TinO2n−1 as a promising support for the BOC has been proposed due to electrochemical stability in acid media and comparable electrical conductivity to carbon [31–33]. In particular, the electrical conductivity of TinO2n-1 structures depends on the value of n [34,35]. In particular, among the reduced structures, Ti4O7 (n = 4) has been known as having a Magnéli phase with excellent electrical conductivity (103 S cm−1) and high stability in an acidic electrolyte [33,36–38]. The oxygen vacancy sites in the reduced titanium suboxide such as Ti4O7 can induce OO bond splitting with increased electric conductivity, and thus result in enhanced electrocatalytic activity [39–42]. Yao et al. proposed improved performance of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) deposited on fiber-like nanostructured Ti4O7 in an acid medium compared to Pt/C catalyst [43]. In particular, Pei et al. reported that a defect in titanium oxide can act as an electrocatalytic active site for ORR [40]. In this study, Ti4O7 as a support for both ORR and OER was prepared using a heating process at 950 °C under an H2 atmosphere with pure TiO2 in the presence of a cobalt precursor. The Pt and PtIr catalysts supported by Ti4O7 (denoted as Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7, respectively) for the BOC were prepared using a borohydride reduction method with a Ti4O7 support. The structure and chemical states of the catalysts were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), field emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The electrocatalytic activity and stability of the catalysts for ORR and OER were evaluated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in an acid medium. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ti4O7 support Ti4O7 as a support was prepared using a low-temperature catalytic reaction with TiO2 and cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate as a catalyst under an H2 atmosphere at 950 °C. TiO2 powder (2 g, Degussa) and 0.2 g cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (98%, CoCl2·6H2O, SIGMA ALDRICH) as a catalyst were mixed in 100 ml ethanol (95%, SAMCHUN) and stirred for 2 h. The precursor powder was collected using an evaporator (EYELA SB-1000) operating at 65 °C and completely dried in a 50 °C oven overnight. The resulting sample as a support was obtained by heating the precursor powder at 950 °C for 3 h under an H2 atmosphere. To remove the cobalt-related compounds, the heated sample was continuously stirred in 1 M HCl solution for 2 h, washed in de-ionized water and ethanol, and dried in a 50 °C oven. 2.2 Synthesis of Ti4O7 supported catalysts To prepare Pt and PtIr catalysts, the intended salt amounts of chloroplatinic acid hydrate (99.99%, H2PtCl6⋅6H2O, SIGMA ALDRICH) and iridium(III) chloride hydrate (99.99%, IrCl3·xH2O, SIGMA ALDRICH) were completely dissolved in 30 ml de-ionized (DI) water (18.2 MΩ cm) as follows: Pt (3.9 mM), PtIr (2.93 mM: 0.975 mM). 100 mg of Ti4O7 powder was well dispersed in 100 ml ethanol and 140 ml DI water with stirring and ultrasonication and the metal precursor solutions were then added to the Ti4O7–disperesed solution with continuous stirring. To completely reduce the metal salt to metal phase, 1.5 g sodium brohydride (99%, NaBH4, SIGMA ALDRICH) as a reducing agent dissolved in 30 ml DI water was added to the metal precursor and Ti4O7 mixed solution with vigorous stirring at room temperature, followed by the reduction process. The resulting powders were washed with DI water, ethanol, and acetone (99.7%, SAMCHUN) and dried in a 50 °C oven overnight. For comparison, Pt catalyst with carbon as a support was prepared using the same procedure as that for the Ti4O7 supported catalyst. 2.3 Structural analysis The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker, D2 Phase system) operating with Kα source (λ = 0.15406 nm) and a nickel filter. The tube voltage and current for the XRD analysis were 30 kV and 10 mA, respectively. To measure the specific surface areas of the samples, nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. The electrical conductivity of the samples was determined using Eq. (2): (2) σ = 1 ρ = l RA where σ is electrical conductivity (S cm−1), ρ is specific resistance, l is thickness of pellet, R is resistance, and A is area of pellet. The morphology of the samples was visualized using a FE-SEM (JEOL, JSM-6700F). The structure and chemical composition of the samples were characterized using a FE-TEM (Philips, Tecnai F20 system) operating at 200 kV. The chemical states of the catalysts were observed using an XPS (Thermo scientific, K-Alpha) with an Al X-ray source of 1486.8 eV. 2.4 Electrochemical analysis The electrochemical properties of the samples were characterized using a potentiostat (AUTOLAB, PGSTAT302N) in a three-electrode cell, which consisted of Pt wire and Ag/AgCl (in 3 M KCl) as a counter and reference electrode, respectively. The inks were prepared by homogeneously mixing the samples with 5 wt% Nafion® solution (SIGMA ALDRICH) and ethanol. The working electrode was prepared by dropping the ink (2.0 μL) on a rotating disk electrode (glassy carbon) and then drying in a 50 °C oven for 10 min. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of the samples were obtained in Ar- and O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. The ORR and OER performance of the catalysts was evaluated using linear sweep voltammetry with a rotating speed of 1600 rpm in O2– and N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4, repsectively. A stability test was carried out by sweeping between 0.8 and 1.6 V for 80 cycles in O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The measured potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the TiO2 powders before and after the heating process under an H2 atmosphere at 950 °C for 3 h. The pristine TiO2 (Degussa) before the heating process had a mixed phase consisting of anatase and rutile phases. After the heating and washing process, the XRD patterns of the resulting sample correspond to those of Ti4O7 as a main Magnéli phase and Ti5O9 as a minor phase without cobalt-related phases. This demonstrates that the dominant Ti4O7 magneli phase can be obtained with a commercial TiO2 via a heating process at a relatively low temperature of 950 °C in the presence of cobalt salt. The low-temperature reduction of TiO2 to Ti4O7 might result from the catalytic role of the cobalt precursor with a proper amount under the reducing atmosphere, as suggested in our previous study [44], as the following equation: TiO2 + H2 + Co(catalyst) → Ti4O7 + H2O(g) + Co. The TinO2n−1 structures as titanium suboxides can be typically formed using a heating process under a reducing atmosphere at a high temperature such as >1200 °C [45,46]. However, it has been reported that titanium suboxides can be obtained by heating pure TiO2 at a relatively low temperature of <1000 °C with transition metals such as Cu, Mo, and Ni [39,47,48]. Reza et al. proposed the Ti3O5 structure as a support using heat treatment at 850 °C with Mo [39]. The specific surface area of the as-prepared Ti4O7 was determined to be 6.64 m2 g−1 (Fig. S1). As shown in the FE-SEM, TEM, and HR-TEM images (Fig. 2 (a)–(c), respectively), the resulting Ti4O7 is a blue black powder with an average particle size of∼500 nm and high crystallinity, representing the d-spacing of 2.47 Å corresponding to the (1 2 0) plane of Ti4O7. Furthermore, the high electrical conductivity of Ti4O7 was measured as 19.8 S cm−1, compared to Vulcan XC-72R (1.9 S cm−1). From the Ti2p XPS spectrum of the as-prepared Ti4O7, the reduced chemical state of Ti could be observed (Fig. S2). The XRD patterns of the Ti4O7 and carbon supported Pt and PtIr catalysts as BOCs are shown in Fig. 3 (a)–(c). Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited the co-existence of the XRD patterns corresponding to Ti4O7 as a Magnéli structure and metallic phases with a face-centered-cubic (fcc) structure. This demonstrates that the Ti4O7 Magnéli phase as a support could be well mixed with the metallic catalysts. In particular, to confirm the particle size and alloy formation of the metallic catatalysts, as shown in Fig. 3(d)–(f), the (2 2 0) planes of the Pt-based metallic phases were compared. According to the Scherrer equation, the average particle sizes of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were measured as 4.1, 3.6, and 4.2 nm, respectively [49,50]. Moreover, the peak position of (2 2 0) for PtIr/Ti4O7 was positively shifted, demonstrating the alloy formation of PtIr on Ti4O7 [50,51]. Since platinum and iridium have the same crystal structure as an fcc and similar atomic radius, the composition of Pt to Ir in PtIr/Ti4O7 can be calculated using Vegard’s law as follows: (3) a PtIr = x · a Pt + ( 1 - x ) · a Ir Thus, the relative atomic ratio of Pt to Ir of the PtIr alloy phases in PtIr/Ti4O7 was determined as 76:24 which was in good agreement with the intentional ratio [52,53]. Fig. 4 (a)–(c) shows TEM images of the metal (60 wt%) catalysts supported by Ti4O7 and Vulcan XC-72R. Despite a relatively high loading amount of metallic phases of Pt/C, the metal NPs as catalysts seemed to be fairly well deposited on the support. However, Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited an agglomerated configuration between the metallic NPs due to the relatively large size of Ti4O7. As shown in the high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images of Fig. 4(d)–(f), the d-spacings of 0.226 nm corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane of the pure Pt crystal structure were observed in Pt/Ti4O7 and Pt/C. Furthermore, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited the (1 1 1) planes of PtIr alloy phases having a d-spacing of 0.225 nm, demonstrating that the relative atomic ratio of Pt to Ir was determined as 3:1. To investigate the chemical states and electronic structure of the catalysts, the XPS spectra for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were obtained as shown in Fig. 5 . From the XPS spectra, the relative atomic ratio of Pt to Ir of the PtIr alloy phase in PtIr/Ti4O7 was determined as 75:25, which was in good agreement with the intentional ratio. All the as-prepared catalysts contained a dominant Pt metallic state (Pt0) with a slight portion of Pt oxidative states (Pt2+ and Pt4+) (Fig. 5(a)–(c)) [54–56]. However, in the case of PtIr/Ti4O7, a similar portion of Ir metallic (Ir0) and oxidative states (Ir4+) was observed (Fig. 5(d)) [57]. In particular, the binding energies of Pt0 in the Pt4f7/2 spectra for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were 70.90, 71.23, and 71.15 eV, respectively, demonstrating a lower binding energy (BE) shift compared to the reference position of Pt0. In general, the modified BE of the supported catalysts might be attributed to an electron interaction between the catalyst and support, resulting in the increased adsorption of oxygen molecules and weak OO bonding [39,43,58]. Zhao et al. reported that the Pt/Ti4O7 with a lower BE shift in the metallic Pt XPS spectrum exhibited significantly improved catalytic activity compared to Pt/C [59]. Fig. 6 (a) shows the CVs for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 in Ar-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4. All the catalysts exhibited typical electrochemical characteristic curves related to a polycrystalline Pt surface structure in an acid medium, i.e. hydrogen oxidation and reduction peaks at 0.1–0.4 V vs. RHE. The electrochemical active surface area (EASA) for the catalysts can be calculated using the following equation: (4) EASA ( m 2 g - 1 ) = Q H M Pt × Q Pt where QH is an amount of charge measured in the hydrogen desorption region, MPt is an amount of the Pt metal, and QPt is 210 µC cm−2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(b) and Table S1, the EASAs for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were 39.28, 51.01, and 29.17 m2 g−1, respectively, reflecting higher electrochemically active sites of the catalysts supported by Ti4O7 with a relatively low particle size compared to the catalyst on the carbon black. In particular, Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7 contained relatively narrower double layers between 0.4 and 0.8 V than that of Pt/C, demonstrating the difference in the electrochemical properties of the support. The Ti4O7 support exhibited a low roughness factor of 39.7 calculated from its specific surface area, compared to Vulcan XC-72R (1516) (Fig. S3). Thus, in the CVs, the Pt and PtIr catalysts on the Ti4O7 support with the relatively low roughness factor showed the relatively narrow double layers. The cathode peak potentials of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7 and Pt/C for the ORR were 0.83, 0.85, and 0.82 V, respectively, demonstrating improved ORR properties of PtIr/Ti4O7 (Fig. 6(b) and Table S1). Fig. 7 (a) shows the LSVs of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C for the ORR with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4. In particular, the origin of the reduction peak in PtIr/Ti4O7 could be related to reduction of Ir-oxide or reductive desorption of oxygen atoms [62]. The diffusion limiting current density of the catalysts (∼5.5 mA cm−2) measured at 1600 rpm corresponded to a complete ORR process approaching 4 electrons without formation of H2O2. The specific current densities of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C at 0.9 V were 0.973, 1.293, and 0.649 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 7(b) and Table S1). The half-wave potentials of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were 0.852, 0.857, and 0.836 V, respectively, demonstrating the superior ORR activity of PtIr/Ti4O7. Thus, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited both enhanced specific activity and half-wave potential, i.e. a significantly superior ORR activity of PtIr/Ti4O7 due to the synergistic effect by the PtIr alloy phase and Ti4O7 support. It has been reported that the Pt-M (M = Ir, Pd, Ru) catalysts with an optimum composition of 2nd metals such as Pt85Ir15 alloy showed enhancement of ORR [60,61]. In particular, the potential for OH adsorption in the PtIr alloy phase is lower than that for OH adsorption on the Pt surface [60,62]. Moreover, the lateral repulsion of OH or O on titanium suboxides can reduce the adsorption energy of the catalysts on titanium suboxides, resulting in enhanced ORR performance of titanium suboxide supported catalysts [39,40,48]. To investigate the OER performance of the catalysts in an acid medium, the LSVs of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C between 1.1 and 1.65 V in N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 were measured (Fig. 8 (a)). The order of the on-set potential of the catalysts for OER was as follows : PtIr/Ti4O7 < Pt/Ti4O7 < Pt/C. The specific current densities of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7 and Pt/C at 1.5 V were 0.26, 1.50, and 0.15 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 8(b) and Table S1). To further clarify the OER properties, the Tafel plots of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 8(c) and Table S1. The slopes of the Tafel plots for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were 107.3, 82.3, and 104.5 mV dec−1, respectively. Using the slope in the Tafel plot, the OER mechanism in an acid medium can be expected [17,63–65]. (5) S + H 2 O → S · OH ads ∗ + H + + e - (6) S · OH ads ∗ → S · OH ads (7) S · OH ads → S · O ads + H + + e - (8) S · OH ads + S · OH ads → S · O ads + S + H 2 O (9) S · O ads + S · O ads → O 2 + 2 S The slopes of >120, ∼60, ∼40, ∼30 and ∼15 mV dec−1 represent that the reactions (5)–(9) respectively, can be the Rate-Determining-Step (RDS) in OER for the catalyst [17]. Compared to Pt/Ti4O7 and Pt/C, the RDS in PtIr/Ti4O7 can be closely related to the reaction (6), i.e. the adsorption of an intermediate during the OER [17]. Thus, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited both high specific activity and low Tafel slope, i.e. a significantly superior OER activity of PtIr/Ti4O7 due to the synergistic effect by the PtIr alloy phase and Ti4O7 support [14,63,66]. Moreover, compared to the ORR and OER performance of the catalysts in literature (Table S2), PtIr/Ti4O7 was found to be a fairly promising BOC in URFCs [17,67–69]. In URFCs, the round-trip efficiency (ε) of the catalysts was measured and compared using the following equation [2,10,20,70]: (10) ε ( % ) = V ORR V OER × 100 where ε, VORR, and VOER are the round-trip efficiency, ORR potential at current density of 1.5 mA cm−2, and OER potential at a current density of 1.5 mA cm−2, respectively. The round-trip efficiencies for Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C were 55.7%, 59.3%, and 54.0%, respectively (Table 1 ). PtIr/Ti4O7 with a synergistic effect by the PtIr alloy phase and Ti4O7 support exhibited the highest round-trip efficiency for URFC due to the improved performance of both ORR and OER. However, while actually operating the URFC, the stability of the catalysts and the activity of the ORR and OER are crucial. To evaluate the stability of the catalysts for the ORR and OER in an acid medium, the cyclic voltammetry was performed between 0.8 and 1.6 V, i.e. the potential range for both ORR and OER, for 80 cycles in O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4. Fig. 9 shows the LSVs of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pt/C for the ORR before and after the stability test. Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited almost the same E1/2, i.e. the ORR activity before and after the stability test, whereas Pt/C showed a significant decline in the ORR activity, i.e. ΔE1/2 ∼ 20 mV after the stability test. Fig. 10 shows a comparison of the LSVs of Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7, and Pr/C for the OER before and after the stability test. Pt/Ti4O7 and PtIr/Ti4O7 maintained the OER performance after the stability test, whereas Pt/C exhibited a serious decay in the OER performance after the stability test [31,36,43]. In particular, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited significantly enhanced BOC properties for the URFC, i.e. improved catalytic activity and stability, due to the synergistic effect of the PtIr alloy phase with a proper composition for both ORR and OER and highly stable conductive Ti4O7 support. 4 Conclusions In summary, Ti4O7 supported Pt-based catalysts were prepared for a bifunctional catalyst in URFC. Compared to Pt/C and Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited enhanced ORR and OER performance and high round-trip efficiency. Moreover, PtIr/Ti4O7 showed superior electrocatalytic stability for both ORR and OER. The improved electrocatalytic properties of PtIr alloy supported by Ti4O7 instead of carbon black might be attributed to the PtIr alloy phase, highly stable Ti4O7 support in an acid medium, and interaction between catalyst and support. Thus, PtIr/Ti4O7 with excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability can be expected to be a promising BOC for URFC. coredata.dc:description: A unitized regenerative fuel cell (URFC) that combines a fuel cell with a water electrolyzer is attractive as a portable power source. To enhance the efficiency of the URFC, a bifunctional oxygen catalyst for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) needs to be developed. In this study, Ti4O7 supported Pt-based catalysts were prepared for a bifunctional oxygen catalyst (BOC) in URFC. Ti4O7 support was prepared using a low-temperature process with TiO2 and cobalt chloride hexahydrate at 950 °C under an H2 atmosphere. The metal catalysts (60 wt%) were deposited on a Ti4O7 support using a borohydride reduction method. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Compared to Pt/C and Pt/Ti4O7, PtIr/Ti4O7 exhibited enhanced activity and stability in ORR and OER. The improved electrocatalytic performance of PtIr alloy supported by Ti4O7 might be attributed to the PtIr alloy phase, the highly stable Ti4O7 support in an acid medium, and the interaction between catalyst and support.
coredata.dc:title: PtIr/Ti4O7 as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for improved oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions
